title: 106_hr1269
content: The "Federal Oil and Gas Reform Act of 1999" is cited as the short title. Section 109 of the Federal Oil and Gas Royalty Management Act of 1982 is amended to include civil penalties for violations related to federal oil and gas royalties. Sec. 109 of the Federal Oil and Gas Royalty Management Act of 1982 is amended to include civil penalties for royalty violations, such as failure to comply with requirements, make payments, or submit accurate information. Violators may be liable for triple the amount of royalty owed. Sec. 109 of the Federal Oil and Gas Royalty Management Act of 1982 imposes penalties for royalty violations, including triple the amount owed plus interest, and a $25,000 civil penalty per violation per day. Violations can be exempted if reported and corrected within 30 days. Lease administration violations include failure to notify the Secretary of designations or assignments and refusal to permit lawful entry or inspection. Failure to permit lawful entry, inspection, or audit, failure to comply with notification requirements, or failure to provide necessary records can result in penalties of up to $10,000 per violation per day. Theft of oil or gas without legal authority or knowingly dealing in stolen oil or gas is also punishable. Any person who purchases, accepts, sells, transports, or conveys stolen oil or gas shall be liable for a penalty of up to $25,000 per violation per day. Repeated violations will result in a demand for compliance within 30 days, with failure leading to a civil penalty three times the original amount. The Secretary may impose penalties for repeated violations of oil or gas lease regulations, including shutting down production, prohibiting lease acquisition, canceling or transferring leases, and collecting reimbursement for costs. Administrative appeals can be made for royalty or penalty determinations. The Secretary can impose penalties for violations of oil or gas lease regulations, with the final determination being subject to administrative appeal. Penalties can be deducted from sums owed by the United States, and the Secretary has the authority to compromise or reduce civil penalties on a case-by-case basis. Notice of penalties will be served personally or by registered mail, and individuals can designate a representative to receive such notices. The Secretary can impose penalties for violations of oil or gas lease regulations, with the final determination subject to administrative appeal. A designated representative can receive notices of penalties. Judicial review is available for those aggrieved by the Secretary's final order, with a 90-day time limit for filing. Failure to pay penalties after a final order may result in legal action. The court has jurisdiction to award the assessed amount plus interest if no petition for judicial review is filed within 90 days. No civil penalty for failure to pay rent on a lease terminated under the Mineral Leasing Act. Violations toll statutes of limitations until corrected. The person must correct violations on oil and gas leases and maintain records until released by the Secretary or expiration of record-keeping period. State sharing of penalties for underpayment of royalties in actions brought under title 31. The royalties paid to the United States under any lease are considered as royalties for mineral leasing laws and the Land and Water Conservation Fund Act of 1965. SEC. 3 of the Federal Oil and Gas Royalty Management Act of 1982 is amended to include trebled royalties or 50% of any civil penalty.
